reviewText:
Ah, Tubo Dismount.  The name alone conjures up images of, well, your mom, actually, but this is not the time or the place for that particular tale.
Anyway, Turbo Dismount is the heartbreaking story of Joe Dismount.  A man trapped in a world that seems to want nothing more than to push him down each time he tries to rise, and hobble him every time he tries to walk.  It's a familiar scene, the cycle of repression which seems torn straight from today's geopolitical headlines.
As painful as it is to watch Joe's agonizing struggles, and I must admit it brought a tear to my eye more than once, we have to face the fact that Joe is not entirely a blameless victim here.  Joe appears to be actively seeking his own demise, and every time we see him dangling from the back of a speeding sports car, or rolling off of a cliff in an office chair, we can only wonder what horrors Joe has seen, or dare I say, even participated in, that drive this insatiable lust for the sweet release of death.
We may never know, for as simple as Turbo Dismount may appear on the surface, beneath lies a complex web of tortured emotion and dark secrets best left undisturbed.  Some may view Joe as a hero, others may see him as a villan, but where Turbo Dismount succeeds in uniting us, is that we can all see Joe torn into little pieces strewn across a highway in the middle of a twenty vehicle pileup.  I suppose that in the end, that's all that really matters.

I had never heard of this game in my life until I saw someone on Youtube playing it.   Then I saw it on steam, then it ended up in my possession.

Turbo Dismount is a simple physics sandbox in where your character clings in humorous and non-safe ways onto vehicals and ploughs into traffic.  Really simple.  The crashes and the ammount of damage is a wonder to behold as you see Mr. (Or Mrs.) Dismount roll under cars and loose limbs and break bones.  The Game also has a replay function where you can slow, rewind and fast foward time so you can see that perfect bone crunching angle.  Also you can dot your path to traffic with Turbo Pads, or Speed Bumps, or Half-pipes or mines for the extra 'umph'.

Levels are rather small but they do their job, and you have quite a selection of vehicals and poses, and when you are bored of what the developers made there is a host of steam workshop levels for you to play with aswell.

And one level of praise I will give the developers, is customization, you can plaster your face, or someone you like (Or really hate) to the puppet Mr (Or Mrs.) Dismount, and you can attach a logo to your vehicals aswell.

It's simple, it's fun, it's cheap, you should own this.

reviewText:
Who knew sending Nicolas Cage into oncoming traffic on a tricycle could be so relaxing?


Turbo Dismount offers a lot for it's 10$ price. It offers a wealth of vehicles to choose from, a massive set of obstacles to play around, different characters, poses and camera angles to play around with on a set of levels, some can be played for hours whilst others get boring fast. Steam Workshop allows you to download user made levels and it's cool to see just how creative people are being with it.


The visual style is basic but offers satisfyingly crunchy sound design for destruction and dismemberment. You have no real control over your car, you simply set the speed and watch it go (however there ais also levels with steering which honestly is quite hard to control) which many people complain about but I personally really like. It gives the game a fun relaxed feel when you don't have to think about where you're going, instead you can just sit back, relax and watch the carnage.


There's also customization which allows you to change the head of your character and the logo of your vehicle which has proven to be absolutely hilarious.

Overall I would recommend Turbo Dismount. A fun little timewaster to turn on for a bit and cause havoc in. I will say however that it's not for everyone and I can see people getting bored with it rather quickly.

7/10

reviewText: I have played the prequel to this game. Stair Dismount for mobile devices. It was one of the best time-wasters I had ever played, and Turbo Dismount, the sequel that I never even fathomed would be made, is even better than the prequel. You have a selection of quite a few different vehicles, from a monster truck to a skateboard to a red Angry Bird to a fire truck and everything in between. You also have different poses to choose from specific to each vehicle. You choose the map, speed, and GET ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING WRECKED by whatever you run into. It could be traffic, a brick wall, landmines, or scenery. It's so fun to see your little dude get mauled by everything in sight. That sounds messed up and quite gruesome, but there is no blood or gore in the game, however, there IS dismemberment, and I'm pretty sure that someone in the future will find a way to make a bloody mod for the game. The physics are well-done in some parts and downright hilarious in others, like when you run into traffic, and then there's a pileup and cars go flying everywhere. If there is one questionable thing I have to say about physics, it's how the guy, if he gets flung into the air, he will slowly stop spinning while in the air. This defies physics and just bugs me a bit for some reason I don't understand. There are also modded levels you can make for the game, which gives the fans something to do to contribute to the game. All in all, this is a time-waster worth the money. It's fun and hilarious and the modding community is very creative. Final Score: 8.75/10.

reviewText:
I'm sure that many of those interested in buying this game were convinced to do so after watching a number of YouTube personalities ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• themselves laughing. I was the same way at one point. Take my advice: just watch those videos some more. They're way more fun than the actual game.

The objective of Turbo Dismount is to orchestrate vehicular accidents that cause as much damage as possible to your vehicle and the hapless mannequin forced into this dilemma. You have at your disposal various maps, vehicles, obstacles to litter the course with, and poses for your mannequin. If you've seen any of the aforementioned YouTube videos, you're no doubt aware of the sort of destruction that can ensue. This would be all fine and dandy if it actually felt like the player had any real control over the outcomes of these crashes.

Accelerating the vehicle consists of holding down a button and releasing it at the moment when a meter is at the desired level. Because of how obscenely quickly the meter fills up and then empties again, precise timing is nearly impossible. This is compunded by the vehicles' tendency to do whatever they want to, such as letting up on the gas when you want them to speed up, vice versa. Many of the obstacles frequently fail to produce an intended effect, and sometimes fail to produce any effect at all. Even in levels that involve other traffic, those other vehicles appear in random order and speed by so quickly that it's nigh impossible to properly time a collision.

The physics engine is capable, but unpredictable. A satisfying crash can have vehicle and body parts being strewn about and colliding with each other in amusing ways, but these moments are scarce thanks to the physics' refusal to behave consistently. It's also frustrating how your ragdolling mannequin often struggles to maintain its pose, or even stay attached to the vehicle, in order to have it hit something in a desired manner.

All of these frustrations combine to form an experience that is usually comprised of restarting a level over and over and over again to get a desired result. When a beautiful catastrophe does happen, it tends to feel less like the results of the player's planning and effort, and more like the result of unintentional happenstance. Even if the player learns the mechanics and nuances well enough to consistently create satisfying crashes, what's left at that point is just a shallow, one-note time waster. Ragdoll crashes car. Ragdoll goes ragdolling. Oh, how the lolz are killing me.

Turbo Dismount is a one-trick pony that ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s up its one trick nine times out of ten. It may be worth getting if you have some easily amused eight-year-old children in your home who are in need of a distraction. Maybe you're into the sort of boring Sunday afternoon that's reminiscent of tossing about Legos in a feeble effort to create imaginary explosions. Otherwise, don't bother.

reviewText:
When I played PAIN for the PS3, it was mostly just a fun little time waster that I would play for minutes at a time before I either managed to pull off the stunt that I had been trying, or I realized I had other games that I wanted to make progress on.

Turbo Dismount is a lot like that. Unlike PAIN, however, I found Turbo Dismount more entertaining.

PAIN had optional objectives that you could complete at any time to unlock a few things here and there, but any sort of objective or unlock system makes screwing around feel kinda weird and almost unenjoyable. You feel like you're not accomplishing anything, and there are things that you might want but you won't get by messing around. PAIN also had an immature sense of humor (using a donut shop to make ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• jokes? Seriously?) that just turns me away for some reason.

Turbo Dismount on the other hand, has no objectives or unlockables. In other kinds of games, this would be a VERY BAD THING. But in a game like this, it works really well for some reason. Choose a level, select a vehicle, and hit the accelerator. And hocus pocus, just like that, you've caused a major traffic pileup (you jerk).
Another great part of Turbo Dismount is how smooth the replay system is. The replay system in PAIN is oddly awkward to use for some reason, but Turbo dismount somehow gets it incredibly right by giving you no controls other than playback speed and camera movement.
Turbo Dismount also features dismemberment (that is not at all gory, because the characters are pretty much just crash test dummies), which makes everything SO much more satisfying. You'll find out what I mean when you ask yourself wait

All you do is drive cars around and crash into other cars (but if you like that sort of thing then I guess this is a pro) I have played it for about half an hour and I got bored really fast, weather thats because I felt rushed to try the game or I just didn't like it. For me, its only fun for about 15 minutes at a time, but who knows, you may like it for hours.


Sidenote: I would absoloutly LOVE this game if there was at least local multiplayer. Like you were both in a car and you could both change your poses and the host could choose to dismount and choose where the obstacles would be.

reviewText:
INTRODUCTION
Turbo dismount is a game I've put a lot of time into. The graphics are great, the possibilities are nearly infinite, and the workshop has thousands of levels. If you want to get the game, yet you are still slightly skeptical, here's my review on Turbo Dismount.

STORY
Oh, story. Yeah, this game has none! The most a completionist can do is play all the pre-made levels and get all the achievements, which will still take around 20-30 hours. The point of Turbo dismount is to mess around with what you got. I've (so far) put around 27 hours into the game and I still can't get enough of the game.

FEATURES
The game comes with some levels to mess around in, but you can always download levels from the steam workshop if you get tired of those levels. You can choose several vehicles, which are all unique in their own way. There's a Tricycle, Fire truck, Wrecking ball, Skateboard, Sports car, etc. If you are wondering, you can choose different characters that can pose and be customized. One of my friends had fun putting the face of Donald Trump on his character, then he would do whatever he wanted to. For poses, there's tons of them, exclusive to each character. Yes, you can do a Miley Cyrus pose on the wrecking ball, and you can do poses on the Wastelander (Inspired by the Mad Max films) that are related to the movies. There's also obstacles you can place down such as a speed boost pad and ramps.

GAMEPLAY
After choosing your character, vehicle, pose, and obstacles, you have to hold down [SPACE BAR] to adjust speed. It's a frustrating task because if you release it at the wrong time, you can go really slow, or way to fast for you to comprehend.  I can still use turbo pads to go fast though, because I usually want to go fast. Characters can have their bones broken, dismembered, twisted the opposite direction, etc, and makes the game more interesting. The physics engine is not realistic though. Once I was using a skateboard and my head got blown off from a wooden paddle when I was only going around a smooth 20 mph ( around 32 kph for foreigners).

AUDIO
The SFX is clear and more realistic than the physics engine. The sounds bones crushing and muscles tearing is what gets me. I probably wouldn't have laughed at this game if SFX and the music weren't there. The music is a jazzy rhythm, and makes the game seem like an overly-edited fail compalation that you can control.

PLAYABILITY
The game has barely any glitches, and recieves laughs from anybody who watches it or plays it. It has the perfect blend of humor and control of paths that I like. This is a must play when my friends come over, and we end up putting 1 or 2 hours of into it everytime. We can laugh at the insanity that happens before our eyes when our character gets blown up by a mine and afterwords mauled by a snow plow. If your mind is thinking Why would you laugh at that

Is this a good, playable, and enjoyable game? Yes
However, it is not worth the $10 pricetag unless you can easily spare this money. I bought this game on sale for $4, and I feel this is a fair price for the game. Why?

With the steam workshop, you will probably get around 5 hours at max on this game, and this is the sole reason the game is not worth the $10 in my opinion. It has a degree of replayability, but you'd eventually get tired of the same track your car follows, the same amount and place of obstacles, and the small maps.

The crash physics are mediocre, and if you want an automobile game with great and realistic crash physics along with a decent amount of mods and replayability I'd reccomend beamNG drive. This game's physics are more fictional and cartoony, but this isn't a downside, rather a different concept.

To the developers (What I think needs to be improved to make this game worth the full price):
- Ability to drive custom paths
- Ability to mod custom models, veichles and veichle properties, obstacles, and physics
- More detailed and textured models, add aesthetical variety to the different maps
- Add the ability to place unlimited obstacles wherever, not constrained to certain spots.
- Larger maps not constrained by an invisible box but instead more aesthetical pleasing walls/mountains/ect.

Again, the theme and concept of this game isn't bad but indeed cartoony" and unique but it needs more features to lengthen it's replayability and add some elements of sandbox. If you enjoy this type of game it's $4 sale price can be a reasonable buy."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If, after watching a YouTube video of this game, you still can't convince yourself that you want to play it, then you're a terrible, joyless person who hates puppies and kittens.

This is the dumbest, most pointless, and outright ridiculous game I have ever played. Turbo Dismount is all of that and more, for it is easily the most relaxing, cathartic experience available in gaming. There is no blood, no violence, merely your featureless ragdoll getting abused and blasted into pieces from various impacts, as seen again and again in instant replay.

This is what a sandbox game is supposed to be. Garry's Mod is more flexible, to be sure, but this is so delightful to pick up and play. You can just enjoy a few crashes, or you can elaborately tweak your path, the obstacles in it, and even the way your character rides on the deathtrap of your choosing. First off: I don't truly hate this game. In fact, there are quite a few good things about it - the degree to which you can experiment with the numerous obstacles and veichles to get different outcomes can be impressive and the courses themselves well-designed, encouraging maximum destruction and crazy hijinks all throughout. Workshop intergration is well-done, with a bunch of user-created levels to play around in, and of course there is always a good laugh to be had from a crash dummy getting as screwed up as possible.

But the fact of the matter is that it's nowhere near as interesting to crash a car for the 100th time as it is to crash it for the first. After about 3 hours of play, I grew incredibly and extremely bored with the repetition of crashing, the bland style of the game, and with the lack of variety overall. After a while, it starts to all feel like 'same old, same old' - just the same freaking thing over and over again throughout and throughout without much difference. Even the Workshop levels (which tend to blow things up the absolute extreme) can't stop the monotony from breaking through.

You might like this game a lot more than I did. You might find the game's explosive antics a lot more amusing than I ever would. You might be crashing cars way more times than I could ever bear. But for me, this game is nothing more - and nothing less - than what it is: a virtual way to crash cars. Over and over and over and over and over again.

5.4 / 10

reviewText:
Less funny than it looks like. Basically you get a bunch of tracks, vehicles, characters and obstacles to cause accidents. You have less control than it seems, you can place objects only where the game allows you to.
Basically you have to push a button and let the vehicle crash into random stuff, far from being interactive.
The physics it's far from perfects, every vehicles (especially the NPC ones) are mostly made of rubber and don't even get wrecked. The ragdoll effect is acceptable, but I've seen better. I don't see the point of having different characters and motorbikes if they can't ride them for more than a few seconds and barely reach the obstacles you have placed. Every other vehicle is mostly useless, ranging from huge, slow and totally unfunny to see crashing to intolerbly fast cars, seeing them crashing after a second from start. Also most of the time your character will fall out of the vehicle before crashing anywhere, thus ending the session very early.
Other than that, you have to follow some predetermined steering paths which the vehicles can't even follow correctly. You have manual steering but it doesn't make the game any funnier.
The default cameras are placed very badly, not letting you see anything. You have to use the manual one which is barely good depending on how you can handle it.

It could have been a good idea, but it's very badly developed. I would rather wait for a fully functional BeamNG.
